<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
Editor's Note
</p>
</td>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: bottom" valign="bottom" width="33%">

</td>

<tr>
<td height="28" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-top: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-radius: 0 10px 0 0; font-size: 0px;" valign="bottom">

<tr>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: separate" width="100%">
<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>The Unicode Consortium released its list of the <a href="https://home.unicode.org/emoji/emoji-frequency/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">most used emojis</a> for the year and, well, you wouldn’t know a global pandemic was going on. The top 10 were: <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/face-with-tears-of-joy_1f602.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/heavy-black-heart_2764.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt="">️<img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/rolling-on-the-floor-laughing_1f923.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/thumbs-up-sign_1f44d.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/loudly-crying-face_1f62d.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/person-with-folded-hands_1f64f.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/face-throwing-a-kiss_1f618.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/smiling-face-with-smiling-eyes-and-three-hearts_1f970.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/smiling-face-with-heart-shaped-eyes_1f60d.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/smiling-face-with-smiling-eyes_1f60a.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt="">.That’s roughly the same list from 2019.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">At first, emojis offended my sensibilities as a writer. “People use these to avoid having to think of <em>actual </em>words,” I grumbled. But then my mom started using <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/face-throwing-a-kiss_1f618.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> in texts, I received my first <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/face-with-tears-of-joy_1f602.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> after sending a joke to the group chat, and my perception of emojis slowly shifted from <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/face-with-one-eyebrow-raised_1f928.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> to more of a <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/shrug_1f937.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt="">. To use <em>actual </em>words, I came to accept them as an inevitable aspect of modern communication.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Still, I find that emojis are best deployed as metaphors rather than substitutes for an existing phrase. And it seems like most people agree: The most popular emojis, according to Unicode, are ones that represent multiple concepts, like the <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/rocket_1f680.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> or the <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/flexed-biceps_1f4aa.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt="">. The most infrequent are country flags, which are largely one-dimensional.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Just never try giving me a <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/thumbs-up-sign_1f44d.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> and we’ll be good.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">—Neal Freyman</p>
</div>
</div>

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/03/icebreakers-with-million-dollar-listing-s-james-harris?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">Icebreakers with...<em>Million Dollar Listing</em>'s James Harris
</a>
</h1>
<a style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/03/icebreakers-with-million-dollar-listing-s-james-harris?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class=""><img alt="Icebreakers with...<em>Million Dollar Listing</em>'s James Harris" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/647a0725a03263d355e398faac72b74c449e6d01-1024x711.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<span class="source" style="display:inline-block;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px"><small><em>James Harris</em></small></span>
</a><div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">James Harris sells some of Los Angeles’s most expensive homes while starring in the reality TV series, <em>Million Dollar Listing</em>, and prepping for the release of his upcoming real estate newsletter, <a href="https://www.readtheblueprint.com/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Blueprint</a>.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">For him, “The real estate comes first, the show comes second,” so we got on the phone and chatted about the real estate market, industry trends, and the bloody (he’s British btw) unbelievable amenities high net worth clients request for their not-so-humble abodes.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>How is the real estate market looking?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It is absolutely fantastic. It's been the strongest year and a half of real estate I've ever seen. The market right now is fueled by interest rates being as low as they are—debt is unbelievably cheap to borrow from the bank. On top of that, the home has always been the sanctuary. But when Covid hit, the home <em>really</em> became the sanctuary, creating a bull market. And that's not just in California. That’s across America and really even across the world.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What are the biggest trends you’re seeing in luxury real estate lately?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Wellness. It used to be, “Oh, we'll just put in a sauna or a steam room and we'll be done.” Now it's like a cold plunge, a sauna, a steam...I saw a house recently that had a bloody surgery room in it.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What's the most requested amenity among high net worth clients?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I don't want to repeat myself, but it is wellness right now. People also love the idea of two kitchens: Having your display kitchen that's galleried in the main living area, and then having a chef's kitchen, which is separated from the main area of the home so that you don't have to make a big mess in your house and you can keep it tucked away from everything else.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>In the LA luxury market, what are the biggest deal breakers for your clients?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">If you can believe it, no elevator. Also, not having privacy. Everybody wants privacy.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What is the next up-and-coming real estate market <em>besides</em> Austin?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Well, everyone's saying Austin right now. But also, all the secondary markets have gone through the roof: Nantucket, Palm Springs, Santa Barbara, any secondary market right now is booming.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Do you have a go-to celebration when you close a big deal?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I don't have a go-to celebration, but I do love to go away for the weekend with my family. And I love to just enjoy time by the beach and actually <em>enjoy</em> the win because a lot of people don't actually enjoy the win. They just go, go, go. And that's what I did for many, many years.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.</em></p>
</div>

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/03/make-it-work-searching-for-management-experience?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">Do You Need Management Experience for a Successful Career?
</a>
</h1>
<a style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/03/make-it-work-searching-for-management-experience?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class=""><img alt="Make it work image " style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7b6de1bb891bb0dd9e289abb0a591582a5da30e6-1503x603.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Each week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers a reader-submitted question about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask Shane here</a>.</em></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>I’ve been working for just over five years and have always been in positions where I don’t have any direct reports. If this stays the same as I progress in my career, does it look bad to potential employers to not have management experience?—<em>Alyssa from NYC</em></strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Save for one notable exception out of New Jersey, you don’t typically get to be “The Boss” without accumulating a bit of management experience first. So where does that leave you, if you find yourself five years into your career without any direct reports or platinum records? Well, like most things, it depends.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Any speculation on what potential employers might value should first be viewed through the lens of your own career objectives. Do you think you’d enjoy management? Do you see yourself in a position that will require you to have direct reports? If so (or, if you’re not sure), it’s worth seeking out opportunities to gain some experience. If you determine that supervising others doesn’t support your long-term goals or interests, perhaps there are better places to invest your energy.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Keep in mind that having direct reports isn’t the only way to level up on your management skills. Leading a project—or any opportunity to train, coach, or mentor your peers—leverages similar competencies. These types of experiences can not only be valuable reference points during job interviews, but they’ll also allow you to gauge whether you find supervising others rewarding.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">If you think you might be born to run from your current job one day, it’s smart to consider how you’ll be perceived by potential employers. And while their specific expectations might be hard to predict, the best strategy is to prioritize experiences that allow you to better understand and develop your own strengths and interests, so that ultimately the way they see you becomes a byproduct of the way you see yourself.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Something bothering you at work? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask Shane here</a>. And if you want to read more analysis about the workplace, make sure you <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/hr/subscribe?utm_campaign=hr_in_morningbrew_sundays&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=crosspromo&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">subscribe to HR Brew</a>.</em></p>
</div>

<tr class="">
<td align="left" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 10px 0px; word-break: break-word;">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;color: #353535; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 22px; table-layout: auto; width: 100%; border: none;" width="100%">
<tr>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">

<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border: 2px solid #353535; background: white; margin: 0px; padding: 10px;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/03/salesforce-adopts-the-dual-ceo-model-but-does-it-work?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">When 2 CEOs Are Better Than 1
</a>
</h1>
<a style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/03/salesforce-adopts-the-dual-ceo-model-but-does-it-work?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class=""><img alt="Meme of two people shaking hands" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/e73e13f56769d83f6f48b9375f996fe6c58821a1-697x500.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<span class="source" style="display:inline-block;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px"><small><em>Neal Freyman</em></small></span>
</a><div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Salesforce president and COO Bret Taylor was <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/30/salesforce-promotes-bret-taylor-to-co-ceo.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">promoted</a> to co-CEO of the company this week, joining cofounder Marc Benioff in the throne room of the world’s largest customer relationship management company.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It’s not the first time Salesforce has tried out the CEO buddy system. Keith Block led the firm alongside Benioff from 2018–2020, before stepping down and leaving Benioff as regular ol’ CEO.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">How does a co-CEO model work? Can it work?</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Not many have tried. Only two of the largest public US firms by revenue had a dual CEO structure as of summer 2020: insurers American Financial Group and Markel Corp.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Along with Salesforce, perhaps the most high-profile co-CEO experiment has been attempted by <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/co-ceos-are-out-of-style-why-is-netflix-resurrecting-the-management-model-11594987416?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Netflix</a>, where Ted Sarandos has shared chief executive duties with Reed Hastings since July 2020. Netflix thinks this arrangement works because Sarandos and Hastings preside over different domains: Sarandos oversees content while Hastings, the company’s longtime boss, directs strategy more broadly.</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px"><li><span>In Netflix’s case, promoting Sarandos to co-CEO also appears to be a creative bit of succession planning so that he can fully take over the company one day.</span></li></ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Management experts have been skeptical of the dual CEO structure for obvious reasons, like awkward power struggles and confusion over who’s actually in charge when big decisions need to be made. After all, Alexander the Great didn’t consult his co-king before invading Asia Minor.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">SAP, the German software behemoth, acknowledged as much in April 2020, when it decided to revert to one CEO from two after a 6-month experiment. It said the conditions brought on by the pandemic require companies “to take swift, determined action, which is best supported by a very clear leadership structure.”</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">And even at Salesforce, which now has two CEOs, it’s apparent there’s still one person who wields the scepter: Taylor will technically <a href="https://www.theinformation.com/articles/salesforces-taylor-will-report-to-benioff-despite-co-ceo-title?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">report to Benioff</a> despite sharing the CEO title, according to The Information.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Still, the dual CEO model is gaining popularity among a certain type of company: fast-growing startups.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Digiday spoke with executives from several <a href="https://digiday.com/media/more-businesses-are-trying-co-ceo-leadership-models-to-help-offset-exec-burnout/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rapidly scaling European firms</a> who have decided to go that route. These startup leaders said the challenges that come with hypergrowth are simply too much for one person to handle—a single CEO would burn out. Two people could better shoulder the burden and foster a more sustainable management team; maybe one could even take a vacation at some point.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Bottom line: </strong>Few companies have successfully pulled off the dual CEO model over long periods of time, and have instead used it as a Band-Aid during crises or to groom new leaders. But as the demands of the CEO role evolve to include fundraiser, recruiter, and even politician, we should expect the role itself to evolve with it.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome to Open house, the only newsletter section that’s not covered in booby traps. We’ll give you a few facts about a listing and you try to guess the price.</p>
<img class="img-responsive" src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-12-03/image-8d02b6e3f394d62a77c0e45fceb367104bb93769-1200x800-gif/winnetka.gif" alt="4 beds, 4 baths Winnetka, IL home. <h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="#">Just Click It
</a>
</h1>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">1. Here’s why movie dialogue has gotten more difficult to understand. </a><div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The main problem with hot chocolate is that it doesn't stay hot. Now you might be thinking, "Wait, that's not a real problem," and you're right.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But there is a real solution to this fake problem, and it's the Ember mug. This high-tech drinkware allows you to keep your beverage of choice at your temperature of choice.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Refer a friend before midnight (ET) tonight and you'll both have a chance to win two Ember products: a mug for the home, and a travel mug for the road.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Plus, every confirmed referral is one entry to win. So the more you refer, the more entries you get.</p>

#353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eThe Unicode Consortium released its list of the \u003ca href=\"https://home.unicode.org/emoji/emoji-frequency/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emost used emojis\u003c/a\u003e for the year and, well, you wouldn’t know a global pandemic was going on. The top 10 were: \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/face-with-tears-of-joy_1f602.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/heavy-black-heart_2764.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e️\u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/rolling-on-the-floor-laughing_1f923.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/thumbs-up-sign_1f44d.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/loudly-crying-face_1f62d.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/person-with-folded-hands_1f64f.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/face-throwing-a-kiss_1f618.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/smiling-face-with-smiling-eyes-and-three-hearts_1f970.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/smiling-face-with-heart-shaped-eyes_1f60d.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/smiling-face-with-smiling-eyes_1f60a.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e.That’s roughly the same list from 2019.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAt first, emojis offended my sensibilities as a writer. “People use these to avoid having to think of \u003cem\u003eactual \u003c/em\u003ewords,” I grumbled. But then my mom started using \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/face-throwing-a-kiss_1f618.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e in texts, I received my first \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/face-with-tears-of-joy_1f602.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e after sending a joke to the group chat, and my perception of emojis slowly shifted from \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/face-with-one-eyebrow-raised_1f928.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e to more of a \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/shrug_1f937.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e. To use \u003cem\u003eactual \u003c/em\u003ewords, I came to accept them as an inevitable aspect of modern communication.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eStill, I find that emojis are best deployed as metaphors rather than substitutes for an existing phrase. And it seems like most people agree: The most popular emojis, according to Unicode, are ones that represent multiple concepts, like the \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/rocket_1f680.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e or the \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/flexed-biceps_1f4aa.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e. The most infrequent are country flags, which are largely one-dimensional.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eJust never try giving me a \u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/thumbs-up-sign_1f44d.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e and we’ll be good.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e—Neal Freyman\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n{if profile.signup_time \u003c time(\"-45 days\")}\n{if ! border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/03/icebreakers-with-million-dollar-listing-s-james-harris?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"Icebreakers with...\u003cem\u003eMillion Dollar Listing\u003c/em\u003e's James Harris\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/647a0725a03263d355e398faac72b74c449e6d01-1024x711.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eJames Harris\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eJames Harris sells some of Los Angeles’s most expensive homes while starring in the reality TV series, \u003cem\u003eMillion Dollar Listing\u003c/em\u003e, and prepping for the release of his upcoming real estate newsletter, \u003ca href=\"https://www.readtheblueprint.com/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eThe Blueprint\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eFor him, “The real estate comes first, the show comes second,” so we got on the phone and chatted about the real estate market, industry trends, and the bloody (he’s British btw) unbelievable amenities high net worth clients request for their not-so-humble abodes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow is the real estate market looking?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt is absolutely fantastic. It's been the strongest year and a half of real estate I've ever seen. The market right now is fueled by interest rates being as low as they are—debt is unbelievably cheap to borrow from the bank. On top of that, the home has always been the sanctuary. But when Covid hit, the home \u003cem\u003ereally\u003c/em\u003e became the sanctuary, creating a bull market. And that's not just in California. That’s across America and really even across the world.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat are the biggest trends you’re seeing in luxury real estate lately?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWellness. It used to be, “Oh, we'll just put in a sauna or a steam room and we'll be done.” Now it's like a cold plunge, a sauna, a steam...I saw a house recently that had a bloody surgery room in it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat's the most requested amenity among high net worth clients?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI don't want to repeat myself, but it is wellness right now. People also love the idea of two kitchens: Having your display kitchen that's galleried in the main living area, and then having a chef's kitchen, which is separated from the main area of the home so that you don't have to make a big mess in your house and you can keep it tucked away from everything else.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn the LA luxury market, what are the biggest deal breakers for your clients?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIf you can believe it, no elevator. Also, not having privacy. Everybody wants privacy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is the next up-and-coming real estate market \u003cem\u003ebesides\u003c/em\u003e Austin?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWell, everyone's saying Austin right now. But also, all the secondary markets have gone through the roof: Nantucket, Palm Springs, Santa Barbara, any secondary market right now is booming.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDo you have a go-to celebration when you close a big deal?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI don't have a go-to celebration, but I do love to go away for the weekend with my family. And I love to just enjoy time by the beach and actually \u003cem\u003eenjoy\u003c/em\u003e the win because a lot of people don't actually enjoy the win. They just go, go, go. And that's what I did for many, many years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/03/icebreakers-with-million-dollar-listing-s-james-harris\u0026utm_source=facebook_share\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\n\u003ca target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/03/make-it-work-searching-for-management-experience?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\"\u003eDo You Need Management Experience for a Successful Career? \n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/03/make-it-work-searching-for-management-experience?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"Make it work image \" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7b6de1bb891bb0dd9e289abb0a591582a5da30e6-1503x603.png?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eEach week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers a reader-submitted question about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk Shane here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eI’ve been working for just over five years and have always been in positions where I don’t have any direct reports. If this stays the same as I progress in my career, does it look bad to potential employers to not have management experience?—\u003cem\u003eAlyssa from NYC\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSave for one notable exception out of New Jersey, you don’t typically get to be “The Boss” without accumulating a bit of management experience first. So where does that leave you, if you find yourself five years into your career without any direct reports or platinum records? Well, like most things, it depends.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAny speculation on what potential employers might value should first be viewed through the lens of your own career objectives. Do you think you’d enjoy management? Do you see yourself in a position that will require you to have direct reports? If so (or, if you’re not sure), it’s worth seeking out opportunities to gain some experience. If you determine that supervising others doesn’t support your long-term goals or interests, perhaps there are better places to invest your energy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eKeep in mind that having direct reports isn’t the only way to level up on your management skills. Leading a project—or any opportunity to train, coach, or mentor your peers—leverages similar competencies. These types of experiences can not only be valuable reference points during job interviews, but they’ll also allow you to gauge whether you find supervising others rewarding.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIf you think you might be born to run from your current job one day, it’s smart to consider how you’ll be perceived by potential employers. And while their specific expectations might be hard to predict, the best strategy is to prioritize experiences that allow you to better understand and develop your own strengths and interests, so that ultimately the way they see you becomes a byproduct of the way you see yourself.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eSomething bothering you at work? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk Shane here\u003c/a\u003e. padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\n\u003ca target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/03/salesforce-adopts-the-dual-ceo-model-but-does-it-work?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\"\u003eWhen 2 CEOs Are Better Than 1\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/03/salesforce-adopts-the-dual-ceo-model-but-does-it-work?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"Meme of two people shaking hands\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/e73e13f56769d83f6f48b9375f996fe6c58821a1-697x500.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eNeal Freyman\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSalesforce president and COO Bret Taylor was \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/30/salesforce-promotes-bret-taylor-to-co-ceo.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epromoted\u003c/a\u003e to co-CEO of the company this week, joining cofounder Marc Benioff in the throne room of the world’s largest customer relationship management company.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt’s not the first time Salesforce has tried out the CEO buddy system. Keith Block led the firm alongside Benioff from 2018–2020, before stepping down and leaving Benioff as regular ol’ CEO.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eHow does a co-CEO model work? Can it work?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eNot many have tried. Only two of the largest public US firms by revenue had a dual CEO structure as of summer 2020: insurers American Financial Group and Markel Corp.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAlong with Salesforce, perhaps the most high-profile co-CEO experiment has been attempted by \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/co-ceos-are-out-of-style-why-is-netflix-resurrecting-the-management-model-11594987416?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eNetflix\u003c/a\u003e, where Ted Sarandos has shared chief executive duties with Reed Hastings since July 2020. Netflix thinks this arrangement works because Sarandos and Hastings preside over different domains: Sarandos oversees content while Hastings, the company’s longtime boss, directs strategy more broadly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn Netflix’s case, promoting Sarandos to co-CEO also appears to be a creative bit of succession planning so that he can fully take over the company one day.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eManagement experts have been skeptical of the dual CEO structure for obvious reasons, like awkward power struggles and confusion over who’s actually in charge when big decisions need to be made. After all, Alexander the Great didn’t consult his co-king before invading Asia Minor.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSAP, the German software behemoth, acknowledged as much in April 2020, when it decided to revert to one CEO from two after a 6-month experiment. It said the conditions brought on by the pandemic require companies “to take swift, determined action, which is best supported by a very clear leadership structure.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAnd even at Salesforce, which now has two CEOs, it’s apparent there’s still one person who wields the scepter: Taylor will technically \u003ca href=\"https://www.theinformation.com/articles/salesforces-taylor-will-report-to-benioff-despite-co-ceo-title?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereport to Benioff\u003c/a\u003e despite sharing the CEO title, according to The Information.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eStill, the dual CEO model is gaining popularity among a certain type of company: fast-growing startups.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eDigiday spoke with executives from several \u003ca href=\"https://digiday.com/media/more-businesses-are-trying-co-ceo-leadership-models-to-help-offset-exec-burnout/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erapidly scaling European firms\u003c/a\u003e who have decided to go that route. These startup leaders said the challenges that come with hypergrowth are simply too much for one person to handle—a single CEO would burn out. Two people could better shoulder the burden and foster a more sustainable management team; maybe one could even take a vacation at some point.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eFew companies have successfully pulled off the dual CEO model over long periods of time, and have instead used it as a Band-Aid during crises or to groom new leaders. But as the demands of the CEO role evolve to include fundraiser, recruiter, and even politician, we should expect the role itself to evolve with it.—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/03/salesforce-adopts-the-dual-ceo-model-but-does-it-work\u0026utm_source=facebook_share\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block;
